title: 35 amazingly useful IFTTT recipes to simplify your life | Trusted Reviews
description:
![IFTT](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

**You’re wasting your life. Yes, you. But luckily, this is going to be one of
those rare times when reading something will actually give you more time,
rather than less. Meet IFTTT and 35 amazingly useful little recipes that will
help you simplify your chaotic life.**

There’s a whole load of ways you could be automating the dullest everyday
tasks and optimising your workflows to make the most of your precious time on
the earth.

[IFTTT](https://ifttt.com/) is short for If This Then That. It’s a service
designed – albeit not with the lofty goal of making the most of your time on
earth – to make it easy to carry out a whole range of tasks via its automated
or on-demand service.

The main IFTTT service is for automatic actions – things that you want to
happen every time certain conditions are met without you needing to do
anything. These trigger > action relationships used to be called ‘recipes’,
but IFTTT recently [renamed them
‘applets’](http://A%20quick%20guide%20to%20IFTTT%20applets). We’re going to
call them recipes for the sake of this article, given that’s what most people
are used to.

As IFTTT is just for automated actions, there’s also another app called DO for
one-off actions that you might like to repeat – like [automatically asking a
specific Slack channel](https://ifttt.com/recipes/192056-ask-a-slack-channel-
if-they-want-coffee-too) or user if they want coffee as you approach the
office.

These are also called recipes, but are marked in IFTTT’s repository as ‘DO’.
(You could also just use an IFTTT recipe for this example, by [geo-fencing a
location relative to your office](https://ifttt.com/recipes/177127-when-
entering-or-exiting-an-area-post-to-a-slack-channel) and setting it to ask the
same question every time you enter that area.)

As Android is a more permissive mobile OS, some of the recipes here won’t work
for iOS devices. Where possible, we’ve included links to both.

## How to automate your home with IFTTT  

**Nest**

![IFTTT recipes
7](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-reviews-
placeholder-3.svg)

Nest might not be the startup darling of the tech scene it once was, but with
a range of smart products that can all communicate together and an open API to
integrate with other third-party devices, it’s one of the companies you should
be considering if you want to automate your home.

There are (literally) hundreds of different recipes available for Nest devices
on IFTTT, depending on what you want to do and what kit you have, but here are
three essentials.

Think you forgot to turn off your lights when you left for your trip? Never
again:

  * **[** **IFTTT** **]**[Turn off your lights when your Nest thermostat is set to Away mode   
](https://ifttt.com/recipes/184018-turn-off-your-lights-when-your-nest-
thermostat-is-set-to-away-mode)

Receive an incredibly handy and potentially life-saving emergency phone call
if your Nest Protect alarm detects smoke. Useful whether you’re in the house
or not:

  * **[** **IFTTT** **]**[Receive an emergency call if your Nest Protect detects smoke](https://ifttt.com/recipes/184130-receive-an-emergency-call-if-your-nest-protect-detects-smoke)

This one depends where you live, really. If you’re in the UK, you’ll be
setting that to a peachy 21ºC. If you’re in warmer climes, you’ll probably
appreciate a blast of the air conditioning for 15 minutes without having to
faff around **:**

  * **[DO]**[Set the temperature to X with a single press](https://ifttt.com/recipes/226636-set-your-nest-thermostat-to-___) / [Switch on your fan for 15 mins](https://ifttt.com/recipes/257271-turn-on-fan-for-15min)

**  
Philips Hue**

****![IFTTT
recipes](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)**  
**

If you’re a Philips Hue user there are heaps of recipes you’ll want to
explore. Obvious ones are like [turning
on](https://ifttt.com/recipes/133323-turn-on-your-philips-hue-lights-when-you-
get-home) your lights when you come home and [turning them off as you
leave](https://ifttt.com/recipes/133322-turn-off-your-lights-when-you-leave-
home) are a starting point, but there are more adventurous uses, too.

You can easily set your Hue to a specific colour or to blink if you’re tagged
in a Facebook photo or receive a message, for example:

  * **[IFTTT]** Social media addict? Blink your lights when you’re [tagged in a photo](https://ifttt.com/recipes/93262-flash-your-lights-when-you-re-tagged-in-a-new-facebook-photo) or [receive a message](https://ifttt.com/recipes/134815-if-facebook-message-is-received-blink-hue-lights)

Sometimes you don’t want a loud, intrusive timer going off, and when those
moments strike, you can blink your lights instead with this recipe:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Blink your lights when your Amazon Alexa/Echo timer gets to zero](http://.%20https//ifttt.com/recipes/303614-when-amazon-echo-alexa-timer-hits-0-blink-hue-lights)

With the press of a button, you can also make your Hue bulbs go through a full
loop of their colour range **:**

  * **[DO]**[Insta-party](https://ifttt.com/recipes/227082-make-your-hues-dance-at-the-party)

**  
SmartThings**

![IFTTT recipes
5](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-reviews-
placeholder-3.svg)

If you’ve got a [Samsung SmartThings](https://www.trustedreviews.com/samsung-
smartthings-review) box hooking up all your connected home devices, there are
a few handy recipes you might want to check out. Note that all of these
require additional third-party hardware.

If you’ve got a [smart moisture
detector](https://support.smartthings.com/hc/en-
us/articles/202847044-SmartSense-Moisture-Sensor), you can set SmartThings to
trigger an alert call if it ever detects a potential leak at home:

  * **[IFTTT]**[Help, it’s wet in here!](https://ifttt.com/recipes/156899-get-a-phone-call-if-smartthings-detects-moisture)

If you’ve got an app-activated smart lock and use the Automatic app in your
car, you can set your front door to unlock when you park-up in a specific spot
– at home would be the obvious place:

  * **[IFTTT]**[Unlock your front door when you get home](https://ifttt.com/recipes/205033-unlock-your-front-door-when-you-arrive-home)

How useful this one is depends on how you use it, it’ll turn your selected
switch on or off. Why is that useful? Because you can do it from the home
screen on your phone:

  * **[DO] Basics –**[Switch on](https://ifttt.com/recipes/259551-turn-on-your-switch)/[off](https://ifttt.com/recipes/259552-turn-off-your-switch)

## How to automate your health and fitness with IFTTT  

**Fitbit**

![IFTTT recipes
8](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-reviews-
placeholder-3.svg)

Fitbit is a company that’s bucking the wearables trend at the moment, in that
it’s actually managing to increase sales rather than seeing them flatline. If
you’re one of those happy Fitbit product owners and you’re not using IFTTT
already, you’re missing out.

For instance, if you just can’t get along with the Fitbit app, then this is
all you need to keep your data in sync on Jawbone’s UP app instead:

  * **[** **IFTTT** **]** [Log Fitbit activity to Jawbone UP app](https://ifttt.com/recipes/176243-log-fitbit-activities-to-jawbone-up)

Never again curse yourself for forgetting to update your weight in Fitbit:

  * **[** **IFTTT** **]** [Update Fitbit Weight when you weigh yourself on a Withings Scale](https://ifttt.com/recipes/176141-update-your-weight-on-fitbit-when-you-weigh-yourself-on-your-withings-scale)

Use these recipes to be woken up either via a phone call or by flashing your
lights once you’ve had a preset amount of sleep. You’ve got two options here,
depending on what hardware you have:

  * **[IFTTT]**[Wakey](https://ifttt.com/recipes/176180-once-i-ve-slept-enough-turn-on-my-bedroom-light)/[wakey](https://ifttt.com/recipes/284363-if-i-sleep-for-too-long-call-and-wake-me-up)!

**Nike**

**![IFTTT
recipes](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)  
**

Nike ‘s IFTTT channel has a load of different recipes to check out (as well as
your own to make), but here are three of the more fun ones that go beyond
tracking and logging.

If you want to make your fitness prowess known to all, set your lights to
flash when you hit your goals. You’ll need a Philips Hue hardware setup,
obviously:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Turn your Hue lights green when you hit your daily goal](https://ifttt.com/recipes/183600-lights-go-green-with-nikefuel-when-you-reach-today-s-goal)

If you use Qapital’s money-saving app, you can turn every run into a way to
put some money away for rainy days. Or really indulgent days.

You could combine this with [a recipe to penalise yourself for missing your
goal](https://ifttt.com/recipes/434892-penalize-yourself-for-missing-your-
daily-fuel-goal) too, which would make every run a ‘win’ **:  
**

  * **[IFTTT]**[Save money when you hit your distance goal](https://ifttt.com/recipes/291919-reward-your-tired-feet-when-you-reach-your-distance-goal)

****

Google Docs

![IFTTT recipes
4](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-reviews-
placeholder-3.svg)

It might seem an odd choice for a ‘health and fitness’ section, but for anyone
really dedicated to tracking their progress, linking up IFTTT with Google Docs
is a no-brainer.

This one is simple. Just set the location of your gym and each time you visit,
then an entry will be logged in a spreadsheet:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Keep a record of your workouts in a spreadsheet](https://ifttt.com/recipes/133209-keep-a-record-in-a-google-spreadsheet-of-all-your-gym-visits)

The ‘Ronseal’ of IFTTT recipes:

  * **[IFTTT]** Save your [Jawbone UP](https://ifttt.com/recipes/91681-save-your-jawbone-up-sleep-logs-to-a-google-spreadsheet)/[Misfit](https://ifttt.com/recipes/200611-save-your-misfit-sleep-logs-to-a-google-spreadsheet)/[Fitbit](https://ifttt.com/recipes/175123-save-your-fitbit-sleep-logs-to-a-google-spreadsheet) sleep data to a spreadsheet

Add your weight, lean mass and body-fat percentage directly to a spreadsheet
to keep track over the longer term:

  * **[IFTTT]**[Automatically record your weight from a Withings scale in a spreadsheet](https://ifttt.com/recipes/149254-automatically-record-body-measurements-taken-with-withings-to-a-spreadsheet)

## How to automate your work with IFTTT  

**Google Calendar**

**![IFTTT recipes
1](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-reviews-
placeholder-3.svg)**

Calendar, unsurprisingly, has a whole lot of useful IFTTT options, but if
you’re a freelancer or workaholic trying to keep tabs on exactly how much time
you spend in the office, you’ll find them especially useful.

Simply waltz in and out of the office – after you’ve set its location, of
course – and your arrival and departure time will be automatically noted in
your Calendar. There’s also [an Android
version](http://www.ifttt.com/recipes/164721) of this recipe:

  * **[IFTTT]**[Track your work hours](https://ifttt.com/recipes/133380-track-your-work-hours-in-google-calendar)

Or, automatically set your Android phone to silent (with or without vibration)
according to your Google Calendar appointments:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Mute your phone in meetings](https://ifttt.com/recipes/165149-mute-my-device-during-meetings)

If you’re in the zone and want to block off your team calendar for an hour so
no one disturbs you, just use this recipe and hit the button **:  
**

  * **[DO]** [In the zone!](https://ifttt.com/recipes/192149-quickly-block-off-the-next-hour-as-do-not-disturb)

****

Todoist

![IFTTT recipes
6](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-reviews-
placeholder-3.svg)

Todoist is a really handy platform for keeping your upcoming tasks under
control and can be used in a whole lot of different ways with IFTTT.

For starters, there’s an easy way to never forget to reply to important emails
ever again:

  * **[IFTTT]** [If an email is starred in Gmail create a task in Todoist](https://ifttt.com/recipes/452644-if-new-starred-email-in-inbox-then-create-a-task-todoist)

Not everything to do with work is purely productivity-focused, though.
Sometimes you’ve just got your hands full (or are just sat on your sofa, too
lazy to move and retrieve your phone from its charger).

This recipe lets you add any item to a Todoist task as you add it via [Amazon
Echo](https://www.trustedreviews.com/amazon-echo-review):

  * **[IFTTT]** [Add shopping list item via Amazon Echo to a task](https://ifttt.com/recipes/299511-echo-add-shopping-list-item-to-grocery-list-in-todoist)

If you have recurring one-off tasks that you want to set yourself – like
‘remember to compile the monthly analytics reports’ – this button lets you
create the task as you set it up and then sets it in motion each time you
press the button **:  
**

  * **[DO]**[Instantly create a new task in Todoist](https://ifttt.com/recipes/256005-quickly-create-a-task-in-todoist)

**  
Slack**

****![IFTTT recipes
2](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-reviews-
placeholder-3.svg)****

By using the [Android Phone Call channel](https://ifttt.com/android_phone),
you can create a recipe that will alert you anytime you miss a call on your
Android phone and post it to a Slack channel of your choosing, including a
private message to yourself.

Or you could just use the one I made for you below **:**

  * **[IFTTT]** [Send missed call notifications to a Slack channel](https://ifttt.com/recipes/452625-missed-calls-on-android-sent-to-a-slack-channel) (Android only)

There’ll be no excuses for missing out on assigned Trello cards if you’re
using this recipe:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Get Slack notifications when a Trello card is assigned to you](https://ifttt.com/recipes/300701-get-slack-notifications-about-assigned-trello-cards)

If you work in a collaborative team environment, you might well want to create
new notifications in Slack each time you create a new note in Evernote. This
recipe will do that for you:

  * **[IFTTT]**[Post new notes to Slack from an Evernote Notebook](https://ifttt.com/recipes/337292-post-new-notes-to-slack-from-an-evernote-notebook)

## How to automate your social media with IFTTT

![IFTTT Instagram and
Facebook](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

Managing your many lovingly-curated online profiles and feeds can be a mammoth
task, but IFTTT has some brilliant recipes to help social media addicts stay
above water.

Want to keep both your Facebook and Twitter profiles up to date with your
latest and greatest mug shot? This clever recipe means you only have to upload
once:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Keep your Facebook and Twitter profile pictures in sync](http://ifttt.com/applets/8981p-keep-your-facebook-and-twitter-profile-pictures-in-sync)

If you’re always the last to know about ticket sales for that once-in-a-
lifetime gig, a simple IFTTT trick with Twitter can make sure it never happens
again:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Get notified when your favourite artist tweets about tickets to a show](http://ifttt.com/applets/apKwXcPx-get-notified-when-your-favorite-artist-tweets-about-tickets-to-a-show)

Been neglecting your Pinterest lately? Turn Instagram into an automatic source
of inspiration using a custom hashtag trigger:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Add to a Pinterest board when you include a specific #hashtag in your Insta caption](http://ifttt.com/applets/305886p-add-to-a-pinterest-board-when-you-include-a-specific-hashtag-in-your-insta-caption)

This similar recipe keeps Instagram and Twitter in sync:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Tweet your Instagram as native photos on Twitter](http://ifttt.com/applets/103249p-tweet-your-instagrams-as-native-photos-on-twitter)

Need a secure place to keep a record of that one friend’s weird and wonderful
Snapchats? Say no more:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Save Snapchat screenshots to Dropbox](http://ifttt.com/applets/102377p-save-snapchat-screenshots-to-dropbox)

## More great IFTTT recipes

![IFTTT awkward
situation](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

If you use [Expensify](http://www.expensify.com) to calculate your expenses,
this nifty Uber recipe will automatically throw your taxi fares into the mix:

  * **[IFTTT]** [Get your Uber receipts sent to Evernote for Expensify](http://ifttt.com/applets/57744p-uber-receipts-to-evernote-for-expensify)

How about a personal eBay search assistant?

  * **[IFTTT]** [Get a daily email digest with eBay listings that match your search](http://ifttt.com/applets/176888p-get-a-daily-email-digest-with-ebay-listings-that-match-your-search)

You’re on a terrible first date. It’s the one time you wish someone would call
you up to tell you about an emergency. This fake call recipe is much better
for everyone, though:

  * **[DO]** [Get yourself out of an awkward situation](http://ifttt.com/applets/192151p-get-yourself-out-of-an-awkward-situation)

If you find yourself always having to explain exactly where you are when
you’re meeting a friend, just save this DO Button trick to send your location
instantly:

  * **[DO]** [Create an Evernote with a link to your location](http://ifttt.com/applets/255327p-create-a-note-with-a-link-to-your-location)
